Posts.Content: I am a 70 year old who has recently been diagnosed with prostate cancer, Gleason 4+3, T1C. Had consultations yesterday with two radiation oncologists and will consult tomorrow with the surgeon. I've read the Walsh and Marks books thoroughly and consider myself as fully briefed on what may be ahead as I can be. Like so many, I personally know a number of men who've undergone treatment of many kinds. The first radiation oncologist has recommended androgen suppression followed by EBRT. The second oncologist is a brachytherapy therapist who laid it all out there for me without a specific recommendation. Tomorrow I expect the surgeon to recommend surgery. I will reach my decision point next week and would appreciate hearing here about any personal experiences with the course of treatment recommended by the first oncologist, above, as even though I am trying to keep an open mind toward the decision there is no question I would lean to that recommendation at this point. Thanks in advance for the sharing of your experience and views. --Flagsin1965, U.S. Navy Signalman Second Class, Vietnam Veteran, Agent Orange Exposee. Biopsy Results with PSA of 6.5: 8-core biopsy performed A-C needle core biopsies, right lobe prostate, apex, mid and base: prostate adenocarcinoma, Gleason pattern 4+3, Gleason score 7/10; perinural invasion noted D needle core biopsy, left lobe prostate, apex: minute focus of glandular atypia suspicious but not conclusive for malignancy E-F needle core biopsies, left lobe prostate, mid and base: no evidence of malignancy
Posts.Title: About to make the decision

Posts.Content: Thank you, Chuck. A little later today or tomorrow I'll add the complete biopsy report to my post so as to make it as complete as possible. PSA history: years and years at 3.0 or below until January 2016 when the VA physical showed a 6.8. Immediately had the private provider do another and that came in at 6.5. Immediately asked for referral, got it quickly, and here we are.

Posts.Title: About to make the decision

Posts.Content: My PSA jumped from 1.9 to 6.5 in a year. Urologist examined digitally, said prostate was "out of symmetry." Biopsy performed, eight cores taken, cancer cells in four. Gleason 4+3, stage T1C. Diagnosed in April, consulted with surgeon, brachy specialist and beam specialist. Chose beam. Gold seeds inserted two weeks ago, simulation done this past Monday. 44 consecutive weekday radiation sessions will start on October 24. Best of luck to you...I'll be watching to see how it's going for you.
Posts.Title: Rapid Rise in PSA
